strategic projects and innovation grants at the Harvard initiative for learning and teaching and if you were to think of
Harvard as being like a big ship I fit in the middle of the university in the Office of the President and provost as a
steering wheel team thinking about where Harvard should be heading with teaching and learning at large and specifically I
oversee a funding mechanism a bucket of money that we give out to people who have innovative ideas around teaching
and learning this fund has been around for about eight years now and it's been really successful with faculty and staff
new collaborations new research new ideas but when I came onto the team two years ago from MIT I looked around and
said hey where are the students right it seemed kind of odd to me that we were having this rich and dynamic
conversation about education innovation and they were like no students they weren't applying for funding and those
who were applying it was like very few people and they weren't being very successful and my team I don't know maybe they're not all that
interested and I said I have a really hard time believing that that's true so
I spent my almost entire first year at Harvard hiring students to help me map
the space and this is really hard because if you don't know Harvard has 12 or 13 different schools they're geographically all over Boston it is not
an easy space to map and first we coded and analyzed all the student groups
across all of Harvard that had anything to do with teaching and learning to look at the patterns and then we looked at
all of the social innovation competitions across all of Harvard to see sort of a cross-section what was
happening with the students who had ideas around education innovation teaching and learning what we found was
really surprising what we found was that 97% of the students who were looking for
resources for their ideas were just hearing now they were getting rejected from their ideas there were over 400
thousand dollars worth of social innovation funding available to students at Harvard and very very few of those
students were getting these big dollar prizes like 75 K for the first prize in 25k for the second it was a
winner-take-all model and everyone else was just hearing no and you can imagine that that's probably not the message
that we want to be sending to bright talented passionate people who want to do good for the world right so I convene
leaders from across the university from the business school the ed school the Kennedy School the innovation labs and I
said hey what would it look like if we designed a really different model one
that had more yeses than nose in it one that taught students about how to innovate firsthand and didn't just award
those who were already being successful and one where we gave as many people as possible the first can experience about
what it takes to take an idea and translate it into action and then outcomes so this past year we launched
for the first time what we now call sorry
operation impact and this is a university-wide initiative so students from all levels across all schools can
participate and we give them funding resources and connections to really help them learn how to take an idea and
skillett go somewhere with it and we you know really designed this
based on the data that we collected we I won't sort of bore you with all the data though my colleagues back at home know
that I do love data um a couple rules we put in place to sort of create the
theory of action that we wanted in this whole thing which was one you couldn't apply alone you had to show us you had a
cross-disciplinary or a cross-functional team that you couldn't have already raised a lot of money for this idea and
we've invested heavily in some fellows some students who already had experience
as being entrepreneurs in education and we require that if you were going to access the funds you had to meet with a
fellow first and we did that because we wanted a couple things we want to make sure that no matter what everybody got
feedback on their ideas number two that they got connected into this network of resources and joined the community and
three we wanted to make sure that everyone heard not yet not now right so
maybe you're not ready for funding yet but go out learn these through things connect to these faculty you take these classes come back next cycle and let's
see what you got right so about Wow I would say at the beginning of the year
we held a kickoff and so many students showed up we really weren't sure if this thing would take off but boy or students
hungry for this resource in our first funding cycle we had 32 teams apply for
funding second 52 teams we hosted a pitch competition and had 67 teams apply
for funding then 30 teams again for our next round of funding and finally this summer we have 13 teams working with us
on their ideas had a little bit of a bell curve right it was about January
where I realized oh my goodness we are running out of resources there are more students here than we thought would come
this team we end this year we ended up funding 60 you teams with their ideas
close to 200 individuals giving them firsthand experience with innovating in the field of education and so I looked
around and I was like oh my gosh they're blowing through their money we're blowing through our money what are they using this money for and it was for web
services and that's when I reached out to AWS and I said maybe we could partner here because they all need support they
all have ideas whether they're working on programs or services or whatever but they see technology is an important part
of their skill mechanism and that's when they started partnering with us so now we give them some funding and some

taking off I mean we originally designed this with learning outcomes as a real measurement how can we teach the most

examples of projects that are coming out of this community this year that we think you ought to be watching the first
is called the Oklahoma science project it is a group of PhD students in the STEM fields who the founders from
Oklahoma where they pretty much cut stem curriculum support and she was upset about that and created a completely
self-directed online curriculum so that even if students didn't have a teacher who had any computational skills that
could still learn self directed on their own some of these skills the next is new
teachers thriving this is a group of former teachers who were really upset at
how many teachers were quitting after their first year and create a professional development program to really support teachers in their first
year and make them sort of continue and retain in the field they piloted in the Boston Public Schools and now have
clients in multiple cities the last is called colorful and it's a group of
women of color who felt really upset as former teachers themselves that there
wasn't enough culturally affirmative curriculum out there and so they've created an Etsy platform of sorts to
